Package org.daiitech.naftah.builtin.utils

Class ObjectUtils

java.lang.Object
org.daiitech.naftah.builtin.utils.ObjectUtils
public final class ObjectUtils extends Object
Utility class providing various helper methods for working with Java objects in the context of the Naftah language runtime.

This class includes methods for:

  • Evaluating object truthiness and emptiness
  • Determining and converting between Java and Naftah types
  • Applying arithmetic and logical operations to objects
  • Handling arrays, collections, maps, and primitive wrappers
  • Converting objects to their Naftah string representations

This class is not instantiable.

Author:
Chakib Daii

  • Constructor Details

    • ObjectUtils

      private ObjectUtils()
      Private constructor to prevent instantiation. Always throws a NaftahBugError when called.

  • Method Details

    • isTruthy

      public static boolean isTruthy(Object obj)
      Checks whether the given object is considered "truthy".

      This method returns false for null, false booleans, numeric zero, NaN, blank strings, empty arrays, collections, and maps. For all other objects, it returns true.

      Parameters:
      obj - the object to evaluate
      Returns:
      true if the object is considered truthy; false otherwise

    • not

      public static Object not(Object value)
      Negates the given value.

      Tries arithmetic negation using NumberUtils.negate(Object). If that fails, it performs logical negation using isTruthy(Object).

      Parameters:
      value - the value to negate
      Returns:
      the negated value

    • isEmpty

      public static boolean isEmpty(Object obj)
      Determine whether the given object is empty.

      This method supports the following object types.

      • Optional: considered empty if not Optional.isPresent()
      • Array: considered empty if its length is zero
      • CharSequence: considered empty if its length is zero
      • Collection: delegates to Collection.isEmpty()
      • Map: delegates to Map.isEmpty()

      If the given object is non-null and not one of the aforementioned supported types, this method returns false.

      Parameters:
      obj - the object to check
      Returns:
      true if the object is null or empty

    • getJavaType

      public static Class<?> getJavaType(org.antlr.v4.runtime.ParserRuleContext naftahTypeContext)

      Parameters:
      naftahTypeContext - the parser context for the type
      Returns:
      the corresponding Java Class, or Object.class if unknown

      Parameters:
      builtInContext - the built-in type context
      Returns:
      the corresponding Java type

    • getNaftahType

      public static String getNaftahType(org.antlr.v4.runtime.Vocabulary vocabulary, Class<?> javaType)
      Maps a given Java type to its equivalent Naftah language type keyword, using the provided ANTLR Vocabulary.

      This method checks the Java class and returns a string representation of the corresponding type in the Naftah language, such as int, boolean, string, etc., based on token types defined in NaftahLexer.

      If the Java type is null or not explicitly recognized, the default type var is returned.

      Parameters:
      vocabulary - the ANTLR Vocabulary used to resolve token names
      javaType - the Java Class to map (e.g. Integer.class, String.class)
      Returns:
      the formatted Naftah type token as a String

    • getNaftahType

      public static String getNaftahType(org.antlr.v4.runtime.Parser parser, Class<?> javaType)
      Resolves a Java type to its corresponding Naftah language type using a parser's vocabulary.

      This is a convenience method that internally retrieves the Vocabulary from the given Parser and delegates to getNaftahType(Vocabulary, Class).

      Parameters:
      parser - the ANTLR Parser instance
      javaType - the Java type to convert
      Returns:
      the Naftah language type token as a String

      Returns:
      true if the object is a built-in type

    • numberToString

      public static String numberToString(Number number)
      Converts the given Number into a localized string representation using Arabic locale formatting rules.

      When the system property arabic.number.format is true, this method uses a preconfigured NumberFormat instance for the Arabic locale. This includes Arabic-style decimal and grouping separators and may render digits in Arabic-Indic form, depending on JVM and font support.

      The method synchronizes on ArabicUtils.ARABIC_NUMBER_FORMAT since NumberFormat is not thread-safe.

      If the system property is not set to true, the method falls back to a custom digit conversion via ArabicUtils.latinNumberToArabicString(Number).

      Parameters:
      number - the number to format; must not be null
      Returns:
      the number formatted as a string using Arabic locale or Arabic digits
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if number is null
      See Also:
      • NumberFormat.format(double)
      • Locale
      • ArabicUtils.latinNumberToArabicString(Number)

    • size

      public static int size(Object obj)
      Returns the size or length of the given object, depending on its type.

      This method provides a unified way to determine the "size" of various types of objects commonly encountered in Java, including arrays, collections, maps, strings, and arbitrary objects. The definition of size depends on the object's runtime type as follows:

      • Arrays: Returns the array's length via Array.getLength(Object).
      • Collections: Returns the number of elements using Collection.size().
      • Maps: Returns the number of key-value mappings using Map.size().
      • Strings: Returns the number of characters using String.length().
      • Boxed primitives: Returns 1 because primitives are considered as a single value counts.
      • Other objects: Returns the count of non-static declared fields in the object's class.

      If the provided object is null, this method returns 0.

      Parameters:
      obj - the object whose size is to be determined; may be null
      Returns:
      the size or length of the given object, or 0 if null
